ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about various critical aspects of development, including morphological processes, gene signaling pathways, and diseases that ensue from disruption to normal processes.

In this course I learned about the developmental processes the govern life. The processes that we learned clearly overlapped with many of the concepts covered in other biology classes like gastrulation, limb development, and regeneration. I found learning about this field of biology to be very interesting because there were so many experiments that clearly depicted the processes and mechanisms that characterize essential stages in development.
In depth overview of embryonic development, along with important intercellular mechanisms that can be applied to other courses

I learned about the various gene pathways that lead to different stages of development within the embryo. I also learned about the different morphological changes that occur over the lifetime of an embryo, how to screen for certain embryonic irregularities, and also stem cell technology.
I developed a good understanding of basic developmental processes.
Dev bio stuff
I got a good understanding of the process of development, from beginning to end, chronologically and pretty in depth

I think I learned how to understand biological processes and how they interconnect. There's a lot of concepts that were important to understand in the context of other topics so it helped me learn to think more holistically.

I gained an in depth understanding of the cellular signaling pathways that give rise to vertebrate and Drosophila development. This course also featured really interesting lectures on regeneration in model organisms (like planarians and hydra) as well as information on organogenesis.
basic mechanisms in developmental biology for mostly zebrafish and drosophila

I really enjoyed this course. Although the lectures weren't always the most engaging, the material was very interesting. The course was at times a bit confusing because the distinction between which processes occurred in which organisms wasn't always clear.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class generally followed a good curriculum and list of topics. It was at times disorganized and hard to follow, which made studying for the class harder. I liked the quiz format because it kept me on top of my studies.

Very informative and educational, thought the material was overwhelming at times, with a lot of focus on minute details that were never tested. A better approach would be to present the information in a more logical and holistic manner than spending ten minutes on the proximal vs distal naming.

A strength of the course are that professors were super knowledgable about the materials that they lecture on. I also really appreciate how the professors didn't pressure students to be super interactive with classes being online, but they were always willing to take questions or took pauses during the lectures for students to ask clarifying questions. The quizzes were a great way to ensure that you kept on track with studying the materials every week. A weakness of this course is that the volume of the information that requires memorization can be a bit overwhelming sometimes. I found most of the content to be quite interesting, but very difficult to fully grasp without spending hours mapping out cascade mechanisms or development processes. Also, I felt as if at time there were significant differences in terms of expectations for the quizzes and exams. The quizzes generally focus on ensuring that you understand the major concepts from that week not the nitty gritty of mechanisms, but then on the exams you would need to include very specific details to demonstrate understanding of mechanisms or gene signaling cascades.
The quizzes were well done and strengthened lecture principles, but the exams were stressful and had some hit or miss questions early on in the first midterm.

A strength would be in some of the lectures. Two of the professors were very clear in their instruction and provided lectures that were easy to follow. However, the lectures were also a weakness as there was one professor whose lectures were very hard to follow and understand. Also, I wish the professors provided more feedback on quizzes and exams. They sometimes did, but I would often get questions wrong on quizzes and exams with little to no information on how my answers were wrong.
The professors teaching the course are absolutely a strength, they were all very great but especially Professor Holley who gave a majority of the lectures.
more problem solving questions on exams rather than memorization ones. but overall very interesting material

I think it was good that there were quizzes every other week, because it helped to keep us in check and studying before each exam. I did also like that there was no Final Exam.

Some of the material felt like it was discussed for too long, but the more difficult concepts were explained well. 

If there weren't lecture recordings though I don't think I would have done well. It was difficult to learn the material the first time you watched the lecture, and while we did have the textbook I feel like otherwise there was not a lot of support for learning more difficult processes.
I think it goes into extreme detail only when necessary which makes it easy to prioritize certain information. However the nature of the exam questions were a bit unpredictable due to the format.

The weakness of this course were the midterm assessments. They were much more challenging than the practice exams from prior years because the format of the exam changed to accommodate a virtual setting. However, the exams became more fair compared to the first exam as the semester progressed.

strengths - weekly quizzes helped to keep me engaged and reviewing course materials. liked it when professors asked thought-provoking questions to engage with students in lecture. no final exam.
weaknesses - barely any resources provided to help students study for exam except for practice exams, and due to COVID online exams, the practice exams didn't help us prepare at all. TA didn't know how to prepare students for exam despite holding review sessions. teaching team could definitely do a better job to show up for students' needs, but they took the usual silence as though everything was fine. class would be strengthened if professors invested more time to provide students with more study materials such as practice quiz and exam questions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the fact that classes were recorded.
N/A

I think that adapting the exams to be all short answer questions was an effective change to accommodate for a virtual setting. Also offering review sessions was a great help when it came to reviewing for the classes. Having the lectures recorded were a god-send when reviewing for the exams as sometimes my notes might have been incomplete and being able to go back and review that lecture was super helpful! I think that recorded lectures would be amazing for the future!

Having recorded lectures was VERY beneficial and allowed me to learn on my own pace, especially if I couldn't make it to class. I also like the virtual office hours. One improvement that could be made is having a Piazza system of communicating with other students about confusing parts of lectures. I felt very isolated from every else, and it also put a lot of pressure to go to office hours to have my questions answered, which wasn't always feasible for me.
The system of weekly quizzes and three exams worked very well, this was one of my least stressful classes.
It was great to have recorded lectures, I don't know how students can succeed without them. I think this should be kept for in person lectures.
na

I wish that the class had felt more like a seminar. Although it is listed as a 200 level core MCDB course and thus I assumed it would be a lecture format, when I realized there were only about 10 other students in the class, I wish we could have had more discussions as a group or time to connect over Zoom (of course, this wasnt a fault of the professors - just one of the downsides to online learning in general)

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I liked the topics. Occasionally, the class was disorganized but I thought the professors cared about their subjects and the students.
Yes, I think it is necessary to take if you want to properly understand cell biology, gene regulation, and development

I would definitely recommend this course to other students in the MCDB major. Of the 3 cores that I've taken, I've enjoyed this one the most by far. I think that material is very interesting and ties together a lot of different ways of thinking about topics in biology from the genetic factors to molecular processes, and also extrapolating to predicting how abherrent processes in development lead to disease. I think that all of the professors were very knowledgable of the materials and encouraged students to ask clarifying questions to ensure that you get as much as possible out of it. While the weekly quizzes can be overwhelming to prepare for they are a great way to ensure that you keep up to date on the content for the exams. Overall, this class was definitely a great choice to take as an MCDB major and I think that it is possible to do well even if you don't have a particulary strong background in bio yet.
It's an interesting course, and Prof. Holley does a great job teaching the material.

I would recommend this course to anyone who was interested by the topics in BIOL 103 and wanted to learn more about them. I also feel like the teaching as a whole in this class is much better than BIOL 103, and there is much more time to deeply understand the concepts of developmental biology.
If the student needs an MCDB core course or is interested in the content is definitely recommend it! It was interesting and not too difficult.
yes, fairly low work and interesting material

If you have to take an MCDB course for you major, this should be one of them. It's easier in comparison to others but you do still have to put in time. There's not really homework, there's readings, quizzes every two weeks and three exams.

Yes, I learned a lot in this course about development and I would recommend this course to any students interested in reproductive or developmental biology. The guest lectures in this course were also super interesting and provided a nice way to learn about the research of multiple MCDB professors.
no. it's a small class so you would assume that there would be better student-professor engagement but the teaching team is not supportive.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture was also recorded for later viewing.
all lectures were recorded
Mostly live virtual lectures, but I would also watch the recorded versions in case I missed class or I need to review certain topics
Lectures were recorded in addition to live.

I watched a lot of the course content asynchronously  being able to pause and restart and modulate the speed of the lecture video was a huge help in studying for exams. Ive struggled with migraines and inattention throughout Zoom university and that flexibility really helped me learn at my own pace.
there were also readings
I rewatched a lot of the lectures and read from the textbook.
sometimes i watched the live lectures, sometimes i missed class and watched the recordings
I also watched the recorded lecture videos when reviewing for exams and quizzes.
